div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: The Sudan.
div.p: Some interesting articles are being contributef to the "Daily Telegraph" by Mr. Edward Dicey on the subject of the Sudan. From the intest to and we make the following extracts:--

div.head: "INVESTMENTS"
div.p: "Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employement of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the Specially contributed Articles are "stock markets and how to profit by them;" "theory if Successful Speculation," "how to start an Account"; "the advantages of 'Call Options"; "Contaigoing Mining and Industrial Securities;" "How to Invest in Mines"; American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Invest,ent Securities by Instalments"; "General Principles for Investors"; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Priniples for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market operators' "Stck Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.p: La Societe Anonyme The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company a ete foundee le 26 Novembre 1904 au Capital de 16,000 actions de L.E. 10 nominal entierement liberees.

Aux termes de ses statuts elle a pour objet l'etude, la preparation et l'execution pour son compte ou pour compte de tiers ou en participation de toutes operations en terrains et immeubles urbains on ruraux, de construction de canaux reservoirs, digues, drains, chemins de fer, tramaways, d'enterprises d'irrigation et generalement de tons travaux d'ame lioration ainsi que de toutes entreprises industrielles se rattachant a l'agriculture.

Despuis la fondation de la Societe, les affaires out immediatement pris un developpement tel que mon seulement le capital original a ete juge insuffisant, amis que meme l'augmentation de capital de L.E. 40,000 prevue par les statuts n'aurait pas permis d'etendre suffisamment les affaires de la Societe

Une assemblee generale extraordinaire des actionaires tenue au Caire le 15 Decemebre 1905 approuve a i'unanimite la proposition du COsneil de porter le capital a 400,000 par I'emission de 24,000 Actions Nouvelles du meme type que les actions anciennes et participant aux benefices sociaux a partir du 1 Janvier 1906.

Gette augmentaiton de capital a ete prise ferme par un groupe de financiers belges dirige par la Banque de Reports de Fonds Publics et de Depots a Anvers, et la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commmerce au Caire.
Sur ces 24,000 actions nouvelles, il en a ete souscrit 13,000 par les anciens actionnaires en vertu d'un droit de preference qui leur a ete reserve.
La solde sout 11,000 actions fait l'objet de la presente emission et est offert au public au prix de L.E. 12 PAR action.

La situation de la Societe telle qu'elle a ete exposes a l'Asemmblee generale ordinaire tenue le 20 Janvier dernier est des plus sati-faissantes. Les beneficies realises dans le coutant du premier exercice ont permis la distribution d'un dividende de 8 1/2% aux actions de capital et P.T. 35 aux parts de dividene.

L'exercice en cours se presente des mainemant sous un aspect des plus favorables. Un lot de terrain acquis I'an dernier vient d;ere realise avec un benefice d'environ LE 23,000 et des offices formesont ete faites a la Societe pour divers autres terrains a des prix qui laisseraien un benefice immediat de plus de L.E. 40,000.
Certaines affaires en participation ont acquis une telle plus value que leur realisation immediate assurerait un benefice considerable.

Ces quelques considerations suffront amplement pour demontrer que des maintenant la Societe a non seulement trouve un emploi remunerateur pour son nonveau capital, mais que I'on peut esperer wue les benefices du prevent exercice suffront largement pour distribuer sur l'ensemble du capital de L.E. 400,000 des dividndes au moins a equivalente a ceux de l'an dernier.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt. AVIS
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoques en Assemblees Generales Ordinaire et Extraordinaire pour le Samedi 21 Mars 1906 a trois heures et demie de l'apres-midi, au Siege Social, au Caire.
Ordres du Jour
Assemblee Ordinaire.
Rapport du Conseil d'Adminsitration. Rapport des Censeurs.
Approbation des Comptes de l'exrercice clos le 31 Decembre 1905
Fixation du dividene.
Proposition de reduction, dans certaines conditions de la quote-part revenant a la National Bank dans les benefices de l'Agricultual Bank.
Benouvellement partial du Conseil d'administration.
Election des Censeurs pour l'exercice 1906. Fixation de l'indemnite des Censeurs.
Asemblee Extraordinaire. Modifications aux Statuts: Article 20 "Elevation a 22 du nonbre maximum de Administrateurs."
Article 22. "Reduction de la duree des fonctions du Gouverneur a cinq ans.

Tout actionaire possedant au moins vingt actions a droit de pendre part aux Assemblees Generales a condtion de deposer ses actions dans T'un des lieux ci-apres designes cu il lui sera delivre une carte d'admission.
En Egypte: Cinq jours au moins avant le jour de la reunion, soit le 18 MARS AU PLUS TARD:

Au Siege Social, au Caire; a la Succurasale d'Alexandrie; aux Ageneces de la Banque a Assiut, Assuan, Benba, Beni-suef, Chibin-el Kom, Damnahur, Fayum, Keneh, Mansurah, Minieh, Port Siad, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig et Musky (Caire); a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank a la Banque Imperiale Ottomane; au Credit Lyonnais; a la Bank of Egypt.

En Europe: au plus tard le 16 Mars: a Paris, et a Marseille; en Italie. dans les bureaux de la "banca Commerciale Italiana;" a Londres. a l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 and 5, King Williams Street. Le Caire, le 25 Fevrier 1906.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. Avis

div.head: Daira Khassa de S.A. Le Khedive. Avis
div.p: La Daira Khasa de S.A. le Khedive a I'honneur d'informer le Public qu'elle met en vente aux encheres, une mouche a benzine nommees Edifinah ayant les caracteristiques suivantes:
Longueur 5 metres et 85 centimetres
Larger 1 metre cinquante centimetres
Prone quarant cinq centimetres
Poupe soixante dix centrimetres
Consommation: Un Kilog et demi de benzine a l'heure.
Vitesse a l'heure 10 Kilometres.
Les personnes qui desirent concourir a l'achat de la dite mouche pourrant la visiter a l'Arseenal des Bateuax Khedoviaux (Boulac).
Les offres devrot etre presentrees sons plicachetes adressees a son excellence le directeur general de la daira de S.A. LE Khedive et accompagnees d'un cautionnement de 10% ad valorem.
La Daira procedera le 20 Mars a 10 heures du matin a l'ouverture des offres. L'adjudicataire devra payer au comptant le solde du ainsi que tous autres frias eventuels.

la Daira se reserve le droit d'accepter ou de refuser I'offre la plus elevee et mems de nedounner aucune suite a I'adjudication sans que les soumissiounnaires puisssent avoir anoun recours contre Elle.

div.p: As Messrs. Lipton, Limited, have taken over Management of the Factory from thr 1st Februray, 1906, it is requested that all amounts outstanding be paid as soon as possible, to enable the President to close his accounts.

div.head: Injured By An Accident
div.p: Mr. W. J. Moore, 11, Pakefield-street, Pake field, Lowestoft, England, is well known and repsected. Although only 25 years of age, he has been connected with religious work for many years, and on most Sundays during the past 6 1/2 year he has ably occupied some village pulpit.

Some months back Mr. Moore wrote us a grateful lefter, telling of the good Dean'Back ache Kidney Pills had done him, and inviting us to send our representiave to get full particulars. This we have now done, and our readers will see that the case teems with interest:--

"It was when the electric tramway was being laid in Lowestoft," Mr, Moore began, "and I was at the wharf getting a load of cement. when suddenly and without warning, several tons of cement sliped, and before I knew what had happened, a bag struck me a glancing blw on the back. It was he worst pain Ive ever known, just as though my back was broken in two. They took me to the hospital, where for 27 weeks I lay hovering between life and death. The doctor said my kidneys were bruised and at length he gave up my case as hopeless, and at length he gav up my case as hopeless, and I was taken home.

Not one of my friends thought I could live. The pains I suffered in my back and hips were just as though you took out your pocket-knife and kept sticking the blade into me. I used to get dizzy and exhausted with the pains, and I suffered agonies from rheumatism as well as gravel and urinary trouble. I plastered my back until it was green, but so no relief could I suffered agonies from rheumatism, as well as gravel and urinary trouble. I plastered my back until it was green, but no relief could I get, and at last I because so weak with the constant suffering that I couldn't keep down a morsel of food. A watery willing came about my eyes, and for a fornight I couldn't see.

I told you in my letter." Mr. Moore went on, "how Doan's Backache Kidney Pills did me good from the start, and how they have. thank Providence, cured me, and I'm glad to have the opportunity of endorsing my letter with my old self again, and I'm as well to day as ever i was; there's no pain or urinary trouble at all. I'm so well, in fact, that for soem time I've been regularly following my new occupation as Insurane Agent, and "the grateful man went on, "I cycle over 100 miles every week, and generally walk frm 10 to 12 miles on a Sunday in connection with my preaching. That will show you what a sound and lasting oure mine is.

I have recommended Doan's Pills to several people, Mr. Moore concluded, "but my cure is the best recommendation that could be, for everyone round here knows how I suffered, and how splendidly Doan's Backache Kidney Pills have cured me."
Doan's Dinner Pills are sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 6 per box, or P.T. 30 for six boxes; or they maybe bought direct from the general agent fro Egypt, Max Fischer Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: Just Out. Reissue with Orgraphical Map of the Nile Valley. Our Sudan
div.p: By John Ward, F.S.A Assisted by Sir Reginald Wingate and his Officers, Sir William Qarstin, Lt.--Col. Count CLERIOMEN, AND and others.
Dedicated by request to Lord Kitchener of Khartoum. Crown 4to 400 pp. 720 illustrations. PRICE 21s net:
Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward, --Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me, I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. all of us who have done out little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that ahs come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the peace and progress' is in fact a sequel to my Fire and Sword in the Sudan.
With the kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely, Rudolf V. Slatin
div.note: To be had of all Booksellers in Egypt.
